In Julia, Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

In Julia, you can write a function to wrap strings by iterating over the words and adding a new line when the text width limit is reached. Here's how you can define such a function:

```julia
function wrap_string(text::AbstractString; text_width::Int=10)
    lines = []
    for word in split(text)
        if length(word) + sum(length, lines) > text_width
            push!(lines, "")
        end
        push!(lines, word)
    end
    return join(lines; separator="\n")
end
```

This function takes a `text` string and an optional `text_width` parameter. It splits the text into words using `split()`, then iterates over the words. If adding a word to the current line would exceed the `text_width` limit, it starts a new line. Finally, it joins the lines back together with newline characters as the separator.

Here's an example of how you can use this function:

```julia
julia> wrap_string("Hello there! This is a very long string that should be wrapped at 10 characters per line.")
"Hello there!\nThis is a very long\nstring that should be\nwrapped at 10\ncharacters per line."
```

In this example, the text is wrapped at 10 characters per line as specified by the `text_width` parameter.
